data.title: Top 10 Best Film Schools in Europe in 2024
data.meta_description: Want to get an Film degree from a leading school or university in Europe? Learn about rankings, tuition fees, accreditation & admission requirements:
data.text:
Author: Justyna Cyrankiewicz ‚Äî Last update: 18 April 2024

Europe is a hub for cinematic excellence, boasting a rich history of film and cinematographic production. The continent‚Äôs schools have educated many of the world‚Äôs most influential filmmakers such as Christopher Nolan, Ridley Scott, Susanne Bier, etc.

As you probably know, Europe also hosts some of the most renowned film festivals, making for quite a robust environment to pursue cinematography in.

üéûÔ∏è Degrees Related to Film & TV

There are many English-taught degrees related to Film & TV; some more practical, some more theory-focused.

Here are some examples:

üèõÔ∏è Film Schools vs Universities

Both film schools and universities offer valid paths to a career in Film. The most important factor, of course, is to acquire the skills you need for your future job.

Film schools often provide a more specialised and hands-on approach, focusing on practical skills and filmmaking techniques.

Conversely, universities tend to offer a broader educational experience that combines film with other academic disciplines, providing a multidisciplinary perspective.

Some private universities, such as Metfilm or Catalyst, have larger budgets and offer equipment and studios to support student projects.

Okay, once you‚Äôve got this, it‚Äôs time to discuss the practical aspects of studying in Europe.

üí∏ Tuition at Top Film Schools

On average, tuition fees for Film degrees in Europe are between ‚Ç¨10,000 and ‚Ç¨20,000 a year for Bachelor‚Äôs degrees and between ‚Ç¨15,000 and ‚Ç¨25,000 for Master‚Äôs degrees.

These costs can vary depending on the subject, country, and level of study. Private universities‚Äô tuition fees can go up to ‚Ç¨30,000 or more.

It‚Äôs also important to consider the cost of living, as many top schools are located in expensive cities such as London, Milan, Berlin, and Copenhagen.

Additionally, you need to keep in mind the gear cost, which in Film is an essential part of studying. Good universities provide equipment to be borrowed for student use, but you still might need to invest in personal materials for practice.

The good news is that some tuition-free options or alternatives with low tuition fees exist in countries like Germany or Austria, especially for EU/EEA citizens. However, admission to tuition-free Film programs can be highly competitive.

üìù Are There English Requirements at Film Schools in Europe?

If courses run in English, students are usually required to provide evidence of their English language proficiency.

The most common tests accepted are IELTS or TOEFL iBT; however, some universities might also accept Duolingo English Tests, Cambridge Certificates, or even completing a university-specific English test.

For example, at the Royal College of Art, if a student has yet to reach the required English language level to begin the program, the College offers an online Pre-Sessional course.

To get specific information, browse through the website of the institution you are interested in or contact their admissions office.

üé¨ Other admissions requirements

In addition to a high level of English, there are other standard admission requirements, such as a motivation letter, a CV, past grade reports, and references.

A film portfolio is not always required, but - as always in the art world - it does add value. Depending on the course you are applying to, it might be a video, a story, or even proof of participating in contests or being active in the industry.

The exact admission requirements vary, so it‚Äôs necessary to check the specific university or school application process. Some universities, like Lodz Film School, may require an entrance exam for international students.

üìπ Facilities at Top Film Institutions

Top Film institutions in Europe often provide state-of-the-art facilities to support student projects.

Here are things that you should look for when choosing where to study:

multiple film studios

at least one green screen studio

dubbing studios for audio

mixing studios

computers and software for post-production and VFX

opportunity to borrow equipment and props

üìΩÔ∏è Career Outcomes

While a degree in Film & TV is most commonly associated with becoming a film director, it may also open the door to other career paths related to movie production, such as:

Cinematography

Screenwriting/playwriting

Film editing

Sound production

Cinematic production

Lighting

Animation

Visual effects

And it is also possible to pursue roles that are part of the film industry but without direct involvement in the filmmaking process, such as:

Film theory

Film history

Film criticism & festival curation

Once you know more or less what path you‚Äôre interested in, you can narrow down your search of institutions by picking between film schools and universities.

üéÄ Wrapping up

In conclusion, Europe offers a plethora of exceptional film schools that can ignite your creativity, hone your skills, and provide a solid foundation for a successful Film career.

Whether you choose a renowned institution with a long-standing reputation or a lesser-known gem with a unique approach, immersing yourself in Europe‚Äôs rich cinematic history and cultural diversity will kick-start your filmmaking journey.
